title: Primes vs. Foot Marks...
content: Aren't primes and foot marks two distinct typographic marks? I've always been under the impression that foot marks (and inch marks, for that matter) have vertical axes, while mathematical primes (and double-primes) ought to be slanted. Please clarify this, someone! :-)
author: mwebert

comments.content:
They're the same thing.

[Unicode](http://web.archive.org/web/20130818043904/http:/www.unicode.org/) defines the following code points:

- <cite>PRIME</cite> (U+2032): ′
- <cite>PRIME, DOUBLE</cite> (U+2033): ″
- <cite>PRIME, TRIPLE</cite> (U+2034): ‴
- <cite>PRIME, QUADRUPLE</cite> (U+2057): ⁗

(In case the above symbols aren't rendered properly on your browser, they're all angled.)

There are other variants of the prime scattered throughout (reversed, modifier letter, and so on), but there is no separate code point for a <cite>foot</cite> symbol. The closest there is is <cite>FOOT, SQUARE</cite>; it's defined in the <cite>Miscellaneous Technical Range</cite> and it looks like a prime hanging inside an opening at the top of a square box.

The [Unicode Character Names Index](http://web.archive.org/web/20130818043904/http:/www.unicode.org/charts/charindex.html) does have entries for <cite>feet</cite> and <cite>inches</cite>, but they are simple cross-references to the entries for <cite>PRIME</cite> and <cite>PRIME, DOUBLE</cite>, respectively.

The [Wikipedia article on the prime symbol](http://web.archive.org/web/20130818043904/http:/en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_(symbol)) supports this.

Perhaps the confusion stems from the fact that on typewriters, feet and inches were represented using the same upright symbols used to represent apostrophes and quotation marks.

I think you're right about the confusion...as least mine, anyway! The "dumb" apostrophe and quotation mark are to blame - they are not acceptable substitutes for prime and double-prime.

Thanks for the clarification.

--Michael.

Yes, although if you use an italic version of them, the dumb apostrope and quote work pretty well as primes/feet/inches.
